I'm currently writing a blog post that uses
[Bayes' Law](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayes%27_law)
but don't want to muddy the post with a review in layman's terms. So
I have something to link, here is a short description and a chance to flex my
[teaching](http://math.berkeley.edu/~dhermes/) muscles before the school
year starts.

Bayes' Law
----------

For those who aren't sure, Bayes' Law tells us that the probability
event
<html-literal></html-literal>
occurs given we know that event
<html-literal></html-literal>
has occurred can
easily be computed. It is written as
<html-literal></html-literal>
vertical bar is meant like the word "given", in other words, the event
<html-literal></html-literal>
is distinct from the event
<html-literal></html-literal> i.e.
<html-literal></html-literal> given <html-literal></html-literal>.
Bayes' law, states that

<div class="katex-elt"><blockquote>
<html-literal></html-literal>
</blockquote></div>

This effectively is a re-scaling of the events by the total probability
of the given event:
<html-literal></html-literal>.

For example, if <html-literal></html-literal> is the event that a <html-literal></html-literal>
is rolled on a fair die and <html-literal></html-literal> is the event that the roll
is odd. We know of course that
<html-literal></html-literal>
since half of the rolls are odd. The event
<html-literal></html-literal>
in this case is the same as <html-literal></html-literal> since the roll can only be
<html-literal></html-literal> if the roll is already odd. Thus

<div class="katex-elt"><blockquote>
<html-literal></html-literal>
</blockquote></div>

and we can compute the conditional probability
<div class="katex-elt"><blockquote>
<html-literal></html-literal>
</blockquote></div>

As we expect, one out of every three odd rolls is a <html-literal></html-literal>.

Bayes' Law Extended Form {#extended}
--------------------------------------------

Instead of considering a single event <html-literal></html-literal> we can consider
a range of <html-literal></html-literal> possible events
<html-literal></html-literal>
occur. We require that one of these <html-literal></html-literal>-events must occur
and that they cover all possible events that could occur. For example
<html-literal></html-literal> is the event that H<sub>2</sub>O is vapor,
<html-literal></html-literal> is the event that H<sub>2</sub>O is water and
<html-literal></html-literal> is the event that H<sub>2</sub>O is ice.

In such a case we know that since the <html-literal></html-literal>-events are distinct

<div class="katex-elt"><blockquote>
<html-literal></html-literal>
</blockquote></div>

Using Bayes' law, we can reinterpret as

<div class="katex-elt"><blockquote>
<html-literal></html-literal>
</blockquote></div>

and the above becomes

<div class="katex-elt"><blockquote>
<html-literal></html-literal>
</blockquote></div>

The same is true if we replace <html-literal></html-literal> with an arbitrary number of
events <html-literal></html-literal>.
